keyTakeAways: Zohran Mamdani's rise to victory in the New York Democratic primary marks the most significant electoral achievement for the Democratic Socialists of America (DSA) to date.
The DSA has seen a national membership surge to 80,000, with 26,000 new members joining since January 2025, driven by Mamdani’s campaign and growing public interest in socialist ideas.
Despite a record 545,000 New Yorkers voting for Mamdani, only a small fraction of rally attendees joined the DSA, highlighting a gap between electoral support and ideological alignment.
Public support for socialism among Democrats is at a record high, with 66% viewing socialism positively compared to only 42% who view capitalism positively.
The DSA has become a central force in pushing progressive policy demands such as rent control, childcare for all, single-payer health care, and prison abolition.
The DSA’s strong stance on Palestinian rights, especially following the October 7 Hamas attack, has become a defining feature of its identity and activism.
Internal divisions remain, including factionalism, purity tests, and de-endorsements of figures like Alexandria Ocasio-Cortez over policy disagreements.

Other progressive candidates, such as Omar Fateh in Minneapolis and Katie Wilson in Seattle, are attempting to follow Mamdani’s model by incorporating DSA-style grassroots organizing and socialist messaging.
Mainstream Democrats are increasingly open to socialist ideas, especially as a response to perceived failures of the establishment to counter authoritarianism and economic inequality.

summaryOfNewsArticle: Zohran Mamdani’s victory in the 2025 New York Democratic primary represents the most significant electoral success for the Democratic Socialists of America (DSA) to date, signaling a major shift in the Democratic Party’s ideological landscape. With national DSA membership reaching a record 80,000 and a surge in grassroots organizing, members are increasingly embracing socialist policies such as rent control, childcare for all, and single-payer healthcare. The DSA’s strong stance on Palestinian liberation and its criticism of Israeli policy—especially following the October 7 Hamas attack—have become central to its identity and outreach. While members like Gustavo Gordillo and Ryan Clancy highlight the growing public demand for political alternatives to the establishment, internal divisions persist, including de-endorsements of figures like Alexandria Ocasio-Cortez and factional debates over ideology and loyalty. The rise of other progressive candidates such as Omar Fateh and Katie Wilson reflects a broader trend of democratic socialist energy spreading beyond national politics into local races. Despite the DSA’s small size and internal tensions, the momentum suggests a fundamental realignment in how voters perceive the Democratic Party’s values and direction.
title: Democratic socialists see their moment in Zohran Mamdani’s rise
